title: Is Team Trump Getting Along Too Well with France?
summary: A bad tax idea gets a surprise U.S. endorsement.. France has contributed many cultural treasures to the world. Its corporate tax policy is not among them. But on a recent visit to Paris, U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin seems to have agreed to help make it easier for tax collectors in France and many other global jurisdictions to maintain high rates on corporate income.

title: Money Pours Into Russia, China, Uzbekistan as Markets Roar Back
summary: Yield-hungry investors pile into emerging-market assets as global central banks turn cautious. Investors are pouring money into emerging markets at the fastest clip in a year, highlighting how many have regained their taste for risk just months after selling buffeted global indexes.

title: Michael Bloomberg Says He Won't Run for President
summary: Former New York mayor says such a large field of presidential hopefuls makes it hard to win the Democratic nomination. Former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg said Tuesday that he won't run for president, citing the difficulty in winning the Democratic Party's nomination.

title: Wall Street to Tamp Down on Default Insurance Bets
summary: Proposal aims to prevent healthy companies from defaulting to trigger swap contracts. title: Bernie Sanders Agrees to Run for President as a Democrat
summary: Vermont senator, an independent, signs pledge to govern as a member of the party if he wins. WASHINGTON-Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders has signed a pledge with the Democratic National Committee to run for president as a Democrat and govern as a member of the party if he wins the White House.

title: Buyer Beware: Hollywood Special Effects Now Permeate Property Listings
summary: Technology lets home sellers change photos to stage rooms with virtual furniture and perform HGTV-style makeovers. summary: Company plans to use chapter 11 process to shut some stores and emerge from bankruptcy with a slimmed-down business. title: New Jersey Governor Pushes Millionaires Tax in Budget Address
summary: Murphy prioritizes raising funding for schools, opioid crisis, NJ Transit. TRENTON, N. J.-Gov. Phil Murphy renewed his push for raising taxes on the wealthy during his annual budget address Tuesday, and pledged to boost funding for schools, the opioid crisis and NJ Transit.

summary: Spy agency once argued the collection of call metadata was vital to national security. summary: Prices have declined around 3.5% in the past five trading days. Gold prices fell for the seventh straight session Tuesday, weighed down by a stronger dollar.

summary: Corey Johnson suggests creating a new agency called Big Apple Transit, or BAT. title: Target and Kohl's Gain as Rivals Shrink

title: U.S. Stocks Inch Lower as Investors Await Trade Signals
summary: New economic data soothes some fears over growth. U.S. stocks ended the day slightly lower Tuesday, after major indexes suffered their worst drop in nearly a month Monday on lingering concerns about global growth and the health of the domestic economy.

title: Somewheres and Anywheres Getting Nowhere
summary: The Anywheres-Somewheres framework is a continuum with plenty of highly educated Somewheres who are inclined to be nationalists and anti-administrative state.. Christopher DeMuth's suggestions for rebalancing federal power from executive agencies back to Congress are fine, but the clinical analysis of "Somewheres" is simplistic and insulting ("Trump and the Revolt of the 'Somewheres,'" op-ed, March 2). Mr. DeMuth, an "Anywhere" conservative with degrees from Harvard and the University of Chicago and decades of think-tank employment, is trying to empathize with and mollify Somewheres-aka left-behinds and deplorables-in the same way that zoologists study lower-order species. The Anywheres-Somewheres framework is a continuum with plenty of highly educated Somewheres who are inclined to be nationalists and anti-administrative state. Anywheres, meanwhile, have political power in large part because many less-educated Americans are dependent on their administrative-state paternalism.

title: Restrain Those Predatory For-Profit Schools
summary: The worst for-profit colleges rake in millions of dollars in federally subsidized loans from low-income students, while too often leaving students owing mountains of debt and facing a lifetime of low earnings.. Regarding your editorial "The Plot Against Low-Income Students" (March 2): The truth is that our Robert Shireman's remarkable career over three decades on Capitol Hill, including positions in the Clinton and Obama administrations, has helped protect countless American students and taxpayers.

title: The Constitution Says Advice and Consent, Not Delay and Destroy
summary: Nowhere in Article II of the Constitution is the concept of "delay, obstruct and torment" included or intended.. Kimberley Strassel is correct in her admonition ("388 Days in Senate Limbo," Potomac Watch, March 1) that the Senate should revise its rules regarding its "advice and consent" responsibility. The Constitution is clear as to the intent and scope of that responsibility, and nowhere in Article II of the Constitution is the concept of "delay, obstruct and torment" included or intended. Of note, the requisite 30 hours of debate allowed for a nominee far exceeds the hours of public debate that a candidate for the presidency faces. Unless there is a specific cause to withhold consent, a matter that should be identified in the committee hearing process, the floor vote for consent should be quick and clean. If the Senate rules of order don't support such action, they must be changed.

title: AB InBev Chairman Resigns to Focus on Other Duties
summary: Olivier Goudet also serves as CEO of JAB conglomerate that owns Keurig Dr Pepper. The chairman of Anheuser-Busch InBev SA is resigning to focus on his role at consumer-goods giant JAB Holding Co., opening up a vacancy at the top of the world's biggest brewer as it grapples with a heavy debt load and falling beer volumes, particularly in the U.S.

title: U.S.-Backed Forces Are Holding 2,000 Suspected ISIS Fighters in Syria

title: View From the Box: CAI International's CEO on the Outlook for Global Shipping

Its marine boxes hold the consumer goods and industrial parts that move across oceans on massive container ships, and its tankers, hopper cars and other rail equipment carry the basic raw materials of the North American industrial economy.

Then it got quiet, and their dog, Gracie, perked up her ears and lowered her head.

title: From John Lennon to Beyoncé-the Story of Tiny Sunglasses
summary: Minuscule sunglasses are a favorite of celebrities and labels like Prada and Balenciaga. But how did they get so small-and can normal people wear them?. AT THE LATIN GRAMMYS last November, Puerto Rican rapper Bad Bunny took the stage in cherry-red sunglasses so minuscule they barely shielded his pupils-the sort of wee shades he's daintily perched on his nose as he's climbed the Billboard charts and mugged his way down red carpets the last couple of years. But the buzz-cut rapper isn't the only advocate of this challenging trend. Rihanna popularized it in the summer of 2017, squinting through angular cat eye frames that couldn't have been much bigger than twin Tic-Tacs. And fellow pop icon Beyoncé has done her share to shrink spectacles; the paparazzi snapped her in pint-sized shades by British eyewear brand Linda Farrow just weeks ago.

title: A Guide to Nashville's Chicest New Neighborhood
summary: The Gulch, a rebirth of the city's old industrial zone, is surprisingly walkable. Here's where to stop for meals, drinks, vintage guitars, detours into intrinsically Nashvillian style and live bluegrass bands.. IN THE GULCH, a shiny young Nashville neighborhood, a $1-billion-dollar master plan is slowly, steadily turning what was once an industrial wasteland between two interstates into a place non-vagrants would actually want to spend a day. If you're on foot the Gulch is easily walkable-though also strewn with scooters from a dockless sharing program. Start at the stairs adjacent to the modern rusted-steel facade of the Gulch Crossing building on Demonbreun Street. You'll descend into the ravine from which the 62-acre (and growing) area gets its name and join the throngs for a southern breakfast at Biscuit Love. Outside the restaurant, you might find one of Amelia's Flower Trucks, retrofitted Volkswagen buses that sell by the stem. Once a month from May to December, vendors fill the asphalt parking lot in the district's center for the Gulch Night Market. It's an enterprising place. Here, a few of the neighborhood's newest sites and text-home-about attractions.

title: Brunello Cucinelli Shares a Few of His Favorite Things
summary: The revered fashion designer on objects of inspiration. "The items are placed on a trunk in a 14th-century castle in Solomeo, Italy. It's become the base for the School of Arts and Crafts that I established in 2013. To this day, it's one of my favorite locations to think, write and reflect. The photograph on the left was taken in 1907 and depicts a church in Solomeo called Saint Bartholomew. We've started restoration work on the church to return it to its original splendor. The books are, in my opinion, of the utmost importance, including Epicurus's Letter on Happiness, Boethius's The Consolation of Philosophy and Yourcenar's Memoirs of Hadrian. At one point, Hadrian says, 'I felt responsible for sustaining and increasing the beauty of the world.' There's a word in the Italian language-sentinella-and it's the idea of being a guardian or custodian. I feel it, too. The statue is of Seneca, a great philosopher from ancient Rome and one of my teachers of humanity. The glass vases are filled with cashmere in the state it's in when it arrives from China and Mongolia. It's the center of my life and my work. In front is a magnifying glass, which I've always used to inspect the fibers of cashmere. Behind that, a holder for my pencils. It's always been a habit of mine to write my notes with a pencil. I also make [design] sketches, and while they aren't beautiful, I have people who understand and interpret them. But if you asked me how to draw a tower or an architectural landscape, that's something that comes naturally to me because I studied engineering. Next to the pencils is a regolo calcolatore, or a slide rule. It's a charming tool that's used for rapid mathematic calculations. When I take a stroll, I never carry my phone with me; in my pocket I usually have a small notepad, a pencil and my slide rule. The world has to be better off than it was 20 years ago. We have more comforts. I believe that technology is a gift from the creator, and don't get me wrong, I want to live with technology. But spending time in nature leads to serenity of the soul; it's a way of life." -As told to Sara Morosi

title: Big-Money Bills Get Little Love-Except in Switzerland

For the cannabis industry, endorsements from the unlikely combination of U.S. food guru Martha Stewart and Canada's statistical agency should help tip the balance.

title: How Virginia Woolf Decorated Her Room of One's Own
summary: In this excerpt from 'Bibliophile: An Illustrated Miscellany' (Chronicle Books), we offer a visual guide to the writing lairs of four celebrated authors-from Virginia Woolf to James Baldwin. Virginia Woolf (1882-1941) and her husband, Leonard, bought Monk's House [in East Sussex] in 1919 and visited frequently. They moved in full time in 1940, when their Bloomsbury, London, flat was damaged in an air raid. The Woolfs loved the property for its lush, informal grounds, including an Italian garden, a dew pond, a terrace and an orchard. The main house was decorated with the help of Woolf's sister, the painter and decorator Vanessa Bell, who lived 6 miles away. Many of Bell's paintings still hang on the walls.

President Trump has chosen an odd time to accuse the Federal Reserve of making the dollar too strong. After all, the dollar is still below December's high and the Fed has changed its tune.

title: Amazon, Long Seen as a Threat to Malls, Is Now a Hot Tenant
summary: Brokers and landlords believe that Amazon-more so than other retailers-has the expertise to draw the right crowd of shoppers. Shopping center owners have long blasted Amazon.com Inc. as a destroyer of their business. Now some are starting to view Amazon as a potential savior.

title: Central Bank Independence Doesn't Matter-Until It Does
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has appointed a central banker from the cabinet. Investors may rue the decision one day.. Central bank independence is under threat as politicians around the world meddle more in monetary policy. Investors, so far, haven't seemed to care too much. By the time they miss it, it may be too late.

title: Borrowing Costs Tumble Across Emerging Asia as Buyers Embrace Local Bonds
summary: Investors say there is still value to be found in local-currency debt, suggesting the rally could run further. Government bonds in some big Asian countries have been buoyed as part of a Federal Reserve-fueled surge in global markets. Investors say there is still value to be found in local-currency debt, suggesting the rally could run further.

title: Former Nissan Chairman Carlos Ghosn Granted Bail
summary: Tokyo District Court set bail at nearly $9 million, but prosectors quickly appealed the ruling. TOKYO-A Tokyo court approved the release of Carlos Ghosn on bail, raising the prospect that the former Nissan Motor Co. chairman could soon be released after 3½ months in jail.

title: Philippines' Duterte Goes His Own Way With Central-Bank Appointment
summary: Political ally Benjamin Diokno is tapped as governor, breaking with a tradition of neutral appointments there. Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte named a political ally to head the central bank, breaking with a tradition of neutral appointments there and adding to concerns about the independence of the country's institutions.

title: Health-Care Industry Debates Hospital Accreditation Rules
summary: CMS receives differing views as Trump administration considers changes designed to rein in conflicts of interest. Companies and organizations tied to health-care accreditation have offered differing views on whether the Trump administration should establish new rules or guidance to curb potential conflicts of interest in the industry, ahead of a possible action later this year.

title: Lawyer for Cohen Approached Trump Attorneys About Pardon
summary: Possibility of presidential pardon was broached and dismissed after April FBI raid on Cohen's premises. An attorney for Michael Cohen, Donald Trump's former personal lawyer, raised the possibility of a pardon with attorneys for the president and his company after federal agents raided Mr. Cohen's properties in April, according to people familiar with the discussions.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Hillary Clinton Says, 'I'm Not Running' for President
summary: She didn't rule out ever seeking office again. Hillary Clinton for the first time Monday ruled out seeking the Democratic presidential nomination in 2020.

title: Reserve Bank of Australia on Hold as Outlook Clouds
summary: Economists expect the resource-rich economy grew by 0.4% in the fourth quarter. Australia's central bank left interest rate on hold Tuesday as expected, but continued to warn about rising risks to the economic outlook.

title: Second HIV Patient May Be Cured After Stem-Cell Transplant
summary: New case involving London man provides new impetus to develop treatments based on transplants. A London man infected with HIV may be the second person to beat the virus that causes AIDS, researchers reported Monday, a finding advancing the costly and challenging search for a cure.

title: China Cuts Growth Target Amid Challenging Economic Slowdown
summary: Premier Li calls for giving foreign investors greater access to Chinese markets. BEIJING-China lowered its economic growth target this year to between 6% and 6.5%, bowing to a deepening slowdown that can't be quickly arrested without aggravating debt levels that are already high.

title: AT&T Breaks Up Turner, Bulks Up Warner Bros. in Major Overhaul
summary: Layoffs expected as HBO and Turner Entertainment combine and Warner Bros. integrates Turner's animation business. AT&T Inc. said it is shaking up its WarnerMedia unit, doing away with an outdated structure in a bid to make the company more competitive in an entertainment industry reshaped by consolidation and technology.

title: Second Canadian Minister Resigns Over Judicial Interference Scandal
summary: Jane Philpott says she has 'lost confidence' in the response from Prime Minister Trudeau's government. A Canadian cabinet minister resigned Monday, saying she has lost confidence in the ruling Liberal Party over allegations it tried to interfere in a criminal prosecution of a global engineering and construction firm.

title: New Art Fair Is Designed to Draw Young Talent
summary: The inaugural MFA Fair in New York City will showcase the work of recent graduates of masters of fine art programs. In New York City, fans of contemporary art have no shortage of fairs to attend, from major exhibitions such as the Armory Show and Frieze New York to smaller, niche-oriented ones.

title: Venezuela Opposition Leader Returns Home, Testing Maduro
summary: Juan Guaidó's arrival to Caracas comes after he broke a court-ordered travel ban last month by crossing into Colombia. CARACAS, Venezuela-Opposition leader Juan Guaidó returned to a cheering crowd in the capital's main airport on Monday despite government threats to arrest him, energizing his supporters in a political showdown with President Nicolás Maduro.

title: Judge Questions Decision to Revoke U.S.-Born Woman's Citizenship
summary: Hoda Muthana, who traveled to Syria to marry an Islamic State fighter, is pushing to return home with toddler son. WASHINGTON-A federal judge on Monday questioned the State Department's decision to revoke the citizenship of a U.S.-born woman who traveled to Syria to marry an Islamic State fighter and now wants to return home with a toddler son.
